abstracts.cdata!:
The PPAR rates project outcome as
            moderately unsatisfactory rather than satisfactory because
            although reasonable success was achieved in meeting several
            of the quantitative targets, several fundamental issues
            crucial to efficient fuelwood supply management were not
            thoroughly addressed, and there were significant
            shortcomings on the demand side. Project sustainability is
            non-evaluable at this stage. Bank performance is rated
            unsatisfactory because project design had significant
            shortcomings despite the long preparation period, and
            supervision was also wanting on several fronts. Borrower
            performance is rated satisfactory. This project offeres
            several lessons for similar interventions in Mali and
            elsewhere, among them: 1) The importance of budgeting
            adequate time and resources in a follow-on project to
            consolidate the achievements and overcome the challenges of
            the predecessor project cannot be overemphasized. 2) It is
            important that appropriate incentives be provided to Bank
            and Borrower project teams so that they design performance
            indicators that monitor outcomes. Only then can effective
            results be achieved. 3) Given the poverty alleviation
            mandate of the Bank, in a Program of Targeted Intervention
            it is important that development objectives be framed partly
            in terms of poverty reduction. This should be done in a way
            that is monitorable and should be backed up in a design by a
            monitoring and evaluation system capable of measuring
            poverty impact.

2438499.trustfund:
TF040610-MALI-BIOMASS ENERGY MANAGEMENT,TF040166-MALI: WEB SITE FOR
            ENVIRONMENTALLY SOUND BIOMASS STOVES,TF035394-MALI - HOUSEHOLD ENERGY PROJECT,TF021535-STRUCTURAL ADJUSTMENT PROGRAM I (SPA),TF020237-STRUCTURAL ADJUSTMENT PROGRAM I,TF020041-HOUSEHOLD ENERGY PROJECT IN MALI,TF025130-PHRD-SAL I AND II (QUALITY
            CIRCLE COMPONENT),TF028304-GEF1-MALI HOUSEHOLD ENERGY

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, and the institutional development
            impact substantial. Lessons emphasize that for a project to
            succeed, government support is required, through new
            transparent regulations, and as in this case, through
            revision, and approval of forest management plans, and
            technical assistance provision. The Government still needs
            to create an enabling environment, with the proviso that
            commercial decisions on fuel-wood arrangements be left to
            private economic agents. Also essential is project ownership
            by the communities, to be achieved by involving local
            participants in most aspects of the project : currently,
            villagers are not only encouraged to actively participate in
            the sustained use of forest areas, but are given exclusive
            user rights over the land. Furthermore, project support
            should provide basic management, and accounting training, so
            that villagers become responsible for dispute settlements
            regarding ownership rights of forest areas. This may also
            induce villagers to establish rural markets, for only if
            benefits are clear to them, will they do so. Institutional
            capacity to enforce tax collection should be enhanced,
            suggested to be collected at the village level, by a private
            subcontractor, while distorted fiscal incentives should be removed.

1552041.trustfund:
TF040610-MALI-BIOMASS ENERGY MANAGEMENT,TF040166-MALI: WEB SITE FOR
            ENVIRONMENTALLY SOUND BIOMASS STOVES,TF035394-MALI - HOUSEHOLD ENERGY PROJECT,TF021535-STRUCTURAL ADJUSTMENT PROGRAM I (SPA),TF020237-STRUCTURAL ADJUSTMENT PROGRAM I,TF020041-HOUSEHOLD ENERGY PROJECT IN MALI,TF025130-PHRD-SAL I AND II (QUALITY
            CIRCLE COMPONENT),TF028304-GEF1-MALI HOUSEHOLD ENERGY

abstracts.cdata!:
The long-term development objectives of
            the Household Energy Project are the reduction of CO2
            emissions, the abatement of forest resources depletion and
            the increased participation of the private sector in the
            management of household energy sector. The implementation
            objectives of the project are to promote popular
            participation in household energy activities, rational use
            of household energy resources and improved end-use of
            household fuels. Specific objectives are: 1) to create an
            enabling regulatory and policy environment for project
            implementation; 2) to provide technical assistance and
            training to peasants, charcoal makers, producers and sellers
            of stoves as well as urban consumers to respectively
            efficiently harvest and carbonize fuelwood, to manage the
            natural forest in a sustainable manner, to effectively
            market new energy end-use equipment and to rationally use
            improved biomass and kerosene stoves. The basic principle
            underpinning this project is that the Government establishes
            the policy environment, but commercial decisions are left to
            private economic agents. The project will consist of two
            main components covering demand and woodfuel supply of
            household energy. The woodfuel supply component consists of
            the following interventions: 1) design of woodfuel supply
            master plans for the main towns and determine the maximum
            annual sustainable wood supply in the catchment areas of the
            towns concerned; 2) preparation of and assistance to
            implement village forest management plans; 3)
            identificaiton, design and implementation of an improved
            carbonization program for local charcoalers; 4) provision of
            institutional support for central and local government
            authorities to help with project management and assist rural
            communities in implementing their forest management plans;
            and 5) launching of a comprehensive training, client
            consultation, and Information, Education and Communication
            (IEC) program on forest management. The demand side
            component will consist of the following: 1) provision of
            institutional support to help with project management and
            private sector production; 2) identification, design and
            assistance to implement a marketing program for the sale of
            these improved biomass and kerosene stoves; 3) support for a
            comprehensive IEC program and systematic consumer
            consultation, executed by private sector operators, on the
            importance of the rational use of energy through the
            purchase and proper use of the improved stoves.
